content: The "Silver Alert Grant Program Act of 2008" is the short title of this Act, which aims to establish purposes for the program. The Act aims to create a grant program to establish and improve State-administered notification systems for finding missing seniors with Alzheimer's and dementia-related illnesses, promote best practices for Silver Alert systems, and increase awareness for coordinated efforts. The Silver Alert Act aims to promote best practices for finding missing seniors with Alzheimer's and dementia, increase awareness for coordinated efforts between families, caregivers, communities, and law enforcement to locate missing individuals quickly and safely reunite them with their families. SEC. 3. FINDINGS; SENSE OF CONGRESS. The Congress finds that as many as 5,000,000 people in the United States may suffer from Alzheimer's disease, with the risk increasing with age. Data shows that 1 in 8 people over the age of 65 have Alzheimer's disease. Alzheimer's disease affects people age 60 and older, with the risk increasing with age. Data shows 1 in 8 individuals over 65 have the disease, and every 71 seconds a new case is diagnosed in the US. The aging baby boomer population will lead to a rise in Alzheimer's cases in the future. Alzheimer's disease affects individuals age 60 and older, with 1 in 8 people over 65 having the disease. Every 71 seconds, a new case is diagnosed in the US. The aging baby boomer population will increase Alzheimer's cases in the future. The Alzheimer's Association estimates that over 60 percent of patients will wander away from their care facilities. The Alzheimer's Association estimates that over 60 percent of individuals with Alzheimer's disease will wander away from their care facilities. States like Colorado, Illinois, Michigan, North Carolina, and Texas have implemented notification systems similar to the Amber Alert to disseminate relevant information. States like Colorado, Illinois, Michigan, North Carolina, and Texas have established notification systems modeled after the Amber Alert to disseminate information about missing seniors and those with dementia-related illnesses to authorities quickly. States like Colorado, Illinois, Michigan, North Carolina, and Texas have implemented Silver Alert systems to notify law enforcement about missing seniors and individuals with dementia, increasing the chances of locating them. Some states have faced challenges in developing such systems due to budget constraints. Congress recognizes the importance of Silver Alert systems. Silver Alert systems in various states aim to increase the chances of locating missing seniors and individuals with dementia. Congress emphasizes the need for clear criteria in issuing alerts and cautions against age-based determinations. Other states have struggled with implementing similar systems due to budget limitations. The criteria for issuing Silver Alerts should be definitive to prevent frequent notifications and not based solely on the age of the missing individual. Alerts should only be for those unable to make personal care decisions and must be initiated by a designated person. The Silver Alert criteria specify that alerts are only for individuals incapable of making personal care decisions and must be initiated by someone who has recent contact with the missing person and is a legal guardian, close family member, resident of the same household, or caregiver. The Silver Alert criteria require alerts for individuals unable to make personal care decisions, initiated by someone with recent contact who is a legal guardian, close family member, resident of the same household, or caregiver, to protect privacy and encourage training for law enforcement. The Silver Alert criteria emphasize protecting the privacy and dignity of individuals, promoting training for law enforcement on locating missing individuals with dementia-related illnesses, and effective communication with them. The Federal Government can assist in locating missing individuals with Alzheimer's disease and other dementia-related illnesses, determining if someone has a dementia-related illness, and improving communication with them. Coordination between State and local entities is encouraged for the Missing Alzheimer's Disease Patient Alert Program. The Federal Government can help prevent injuries and loss of life among individuals with Alzheimer's disease by supporting States in establishing and improving Silver Alert systems. Coordination between State and local entities is encouraged for the Missing Alzheimer's Disease Patient Alert Program. The Silver Alert System Grant Program is established to support States in improving systems for individuals with Alzheimer's disease. Coordination between State and local entities is encouraged for the Missing Alzheimer's Disease Patient Alert Program. The Attorney General can award grants to States to establish or improve Silver Alert systems. Grants are for a one-year period and must be at least $100,000. Regulations must be established within one year. The Attorney General can award grants to States for Silver Alert systems, with a minimum amount of $100,000. Regulations must be established within one year for eligibility, application, and selection criteria. The Attorney General will prescribe regulations for States to receive grants under the Silver Alert system, including eligibility, application, and selection criteria. $5,600,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2009 to 2013. Annual report on Silver Alert systems. The Attorney General must provide an annual report to Congress on Silver Alert systems, listing states with such systems and detailing the number of alerts issued, individuals located successfully, and the average time taken to locate them. The annual report to Congress on Silver Alert systems includes details such as the number of alerts issued, individuals located successfully, average time taken to locate them, issuing agency, dissemination process, cost, and criteria used by states. The annual report to Congress on Silver Alert systems includes details on the issuing agency, dissemination process, cost, criteria for issuing alerts, actions taken to protect privacy and dignity of individuals, and if missing individuals crossed state lines. The annual report to Congress on Silver Alert systems includes criteria for issuing alerts, actions taken to protect privacy and dignity of individuals, communication improvements between families and authorities, and any other relevant information determined by the Attorney General. The Silver Alert system is a State-administered notification system to locate missing individuals with Alzheimer's disease and other dementia-related illnesses. The term "State" refers to various regions within the United States and its territories.
